**Short answer**

When the entire life‑cycle of each fuel is taken into account – mining or extraction, plant construction, operation, fuel‑cycle processing, waste handling, decommissioning and (for coal) the health impacts of the air‑pollution that is released – most peer‑reviewed assessments find that **nuclear power results in far fewer deaths per unit of electricity generated than coal**.  

The most frequently quoted metric is **deaths per terawatt‑hour (TWh) of electricity produced**.  Across a wide range of studies the median estimates are roughly  

| Energy source | Median deaths / TWh (range) |
|---------------|-----------------------------|
| Coal (including mining, plant operation, air‑pollution, and climate‑related effects) | **24 – 78** (most recent WHO/IEA‐based assessments cluster around **30 – 45**) |
| Nuclear (including mining, plant construction, operation, accidents, waste management, decommissioning) | **0.07 – 0.2** (most recent meta‑analyses cluster around **0.09 – 0.12**) |

In other words, **coal causes about 300 – 1 500 times more deaths per TWh than nuclear**, even when the rare but high‑impact nuclear accidents are included.
